awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Citing Structured and Evolving Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Citation is an essential part of scientific publishing and, more generally, of scholarship.  It is used to gauge the trust placed in published information and, for better or for worse, is an important factor in judging academic reputation. Now that so much scientific publishing involves data and takes place through a database rather than conventional journals, how is some part of a database to be cited? More generally, how should data stored in a repository that has complex internal structure and that is subject to change be cited?

The goal of this research is to develop a framework for data citation which takes into account the increasingly large number of possible citations; the need for citations to be both human and machine readable; and the need for citations to conform to various specifications and standards. A basic assumption is that citations must be generated, on the fly, from the database.  The framework is validated by a prototype system in which citations conforming to pre-specified standards are automatically generated from the data, and tested on operational databases of pharmacological and Earth science data.  The broader impact of this research is on scientists who publish their findings in organized data collections or databases; data centers that publish and preserve data; businesses and government agencies that provide on-line reference works; and on various organizations who formulate data citation principles. The research also tackles the issue of how to enrich linked data so that it can be properly cited.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Abstract

This research developed the OPeNDAP Citation Creator (OCCUR), a web service that creates identifiers and citations for data served by the Open-source Project for a Network Data Access Protocol (OPeNDAP). As a partial implementation of the Research Data Alliance (RDA) Working Group on Data Citation (WGDC) guidelines, OCCUR addresses the need to identify arbitrary subsets of revisable datasets. OCCUR creates and stores identifiers, which are a combination of an OPeNDAP query, a timestamp, and a hash of the query's result set. OCCUR can de-reference these identifiers to access the referenced data and/or to generate human-readable citation snippets. When accessing data via the identifier, OCCUR compares the saved hash with the hash of the retrieved data to determine whether the data has changed since it was identified. OCCUR leverages CiteProc to create the formatted citation snippets.

Background

Citations provide identity, attribution, and access mechanisms for cited material. Data citations differ from citations of printed material in that the cited content may evolve over time, and meta-information such as authorship or provenance may vary within a continuous dataset. Further, data citations cannot be statically generated for subsettable data, unless the number of possible subsets is trivially small. This is especially true when data, rather than files, are accessed through application programming interfaces (APIs). Data citations therefore have to be machine-actionable, both in terms of dynamic creation (as a function of time and subsetting parameters) and in terms of resolving citations to the cited material.

OPeNDAP simplifies access to remote data. OPeNDAP is most widely used to access remote scientific datasets stored as HDF or netCDF files. In addition to arbitrary data subsets, an OPeNDAP server allows an OPeNDAP client to request structural and descriptive metadata.

OCCUR

OCCUR extends OPeNDAP, allowing users to convert OPeNDAP queries into formatted citation snippets, analogous to the service www.crosscite.org provides for DOIs. OCCUR extracts the required citation information from the OPeNDAP data query, from additional metadata queries to the OPeNDAP server, and optionally from any DOIs provided by the OCCUR client.

OCCUR further allows the creation and storage of unique, fixed identities for OPeNDAP data subsets. A stored identiy can later be resolved through OCCUR, whereby OCCUR will verify that the data has not changed and therefore assures fixity of the refrenced state of the data. (Note that OCCUR does not enable fixity of the data itself; but instead follows an opportunistic approach for de-referencing identities: An identifier can only be de-referenced during the time interval between identity creation and such time as the state of the referenced data changes.)

In summary, OCCUR is implemented as a web service that allows users to:

  1. Assign and store identities to data.

  2. Create identifiers for those identities.

  3. Resolve identifiers to the data. While de-referencing, OCCUR verifies that the data has not changed since the creation of the identifier.

  4. Broker identities; i.e. ensure that identical data is sharing the same identity.

  5. Generate formatted citation snippets for OCCUR identifiers.

OCCUR is built as a 3rd party web service without any need for modification of the data repositories themselves. It is meant to be a proof-of-concept that may be adapted to other RESTful data access services such as WMS and WCS. OCCUR could remain a 3rd-party system, or it could be integrated into the data services themselves.

OCCUR is currently maintained at https://github.com/NiklasPhabian/occur

 


Last Modified: 05/17/2022
Modified by: James Frew
